revised_title: Olfactory Conditioning in Parasitic Insects and its Relation to Host Selection
tldr: The authors conducted experiments with the parasitic insect Nemeritis canescens to study how olfactory conditioning affects host selection. They found that the insect is strongly attracted to the smell of its host and can be conditioned to prefer specific host species. This conditioning could play a role in the development of biological races within insect species that breed on multiple hosts. The study provides insights into the complex relationship between insects and their hosts and the factors that influence their interactions.
